WHO WE ARE AND WHAT WE DO:  Established in 1905[co] the Forest Service is an agency of the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA). The USDA Forest Service administers programs for applying sound conservation and utilization practices to natural resources of the national forests and national grasslands[co] for promoting these practices on all forest lands through cooperation with states and private landowners[co] and for carrying out extensive forest and range research to meet the needs of present and future generations. The Forest Service is also the largest forestry research organization in the world[co] and provides technical and financial assistance to state and private forestry agencies.
National Forests are America[ap]s great outdoors. They encompass 191 million acres of land[co] which is an area equivalent to the size of Texas. National forests provide opportunities for recreation in open spaces and natural environments. With more and more people living in urban areas[co] national forests are becoming more important and valuable to Americans. People enjoy a wide variety of activities on national forests[co] including backpacking in remote and unroaded wilderness areas[co] mastering an all-terrain vehicle over a challenging trail[co] enjoying the views along a scenic byway[co] or fishing on a great trout stream[co] to mention just a few.
Gifford Pinchot[co] the first Chief of the Forest Service[co] summed up the purpose of the Forest Service – "to provide the greatest amount of good for the greatest amount of people in the long run."
The Forest Service has a workforce of approximately 30[co]000 employees that reflects the full range of diversity of the American people. This includes cultural and disciplinary diversity[co] as well as diversity in skills and abilities.
The Forest Service motto[co] "Caring for the Land and Serving People" captures the spirit of our mission[co] which we accomplish through five main activities:
1. Protection and management of natural resources on National Forest System lands.
2. Research on all aspects of forestry[co] rangeland management[co] and forest resource utilization.
3. Community assistance and cooperation with State and local governments[co] forest industries[co] and private landowners to help protect and manage non-Federal forest and associated range and watershed lands to improve conditions in rural areas.
4. Achieving and supporting an effective workforce that reflects the full range of diversity of the American people.
5. International assistance in formulating policy and coordinating U.S. support for the protection and sound management of the world[ap]s forest resources.
For more information about the Forest Service[co] visit our website at http://www.fs.fed.us/ .
